title: Riot this, is not okay <_<
body:
https://clips.twitch.tv/PluckyDistinctClintOhMyDog

 How do these kind of changes even make it to live?

replies.body:
Unfortunately . . . 
"PBE isn't for balancing, but bug testing" 
Which has been a mistake for years.

Not a single player treats PBE with the respect a tester should have for the environment so don't you even dare trying to blame that on Riot. Likewise, PBE is a small fraction of any major server player wise and what can get tested in a couple of days on Live, is likely taking a week or more for the smaller player pool, on the good days.

In any case, players don't mostly don't care about their PBE accounts and wouldn't mind losing them for whatever reason. That doesn't mean they do stupid things there but ragequits, afks and leaves happen very frequently and people are mostly there to try out new content for the first time and never get into a game until something else that's new is released once more.

As a PBE tester, I can say a large part of this kind of is Riot's fault too, though. The application process is lax, and there are absolutely no expectations of testers there. To many, PBE has become a playground where you get all of your toys unlocked for free and get to be as toxic as you want without getting punished, because Riot has pretty much no PBE presence, nor do they do any kind of quality control. Testers aren't asked, let alone required to contribute, and often the feedback they give is ignored anyway. Well-documented bug reports posted by multiple players are left unanswered for months after a champion, rework or skin launches, even for years in some cases (e.g. the Mordekaiser rework), balance feedback is ignored because of the one time Riot overbuffed juggernauts, and design feedback isn't even considered, as whichever kit is released on the PBE is usually assumed to be the final product. Not only are players not expected to actually test on PBE, they're brought in under the assumption that they can give feedback for anything, yet are largely ignored even when they do try to contribute. PBE is effectively just a showcase for upcoming content via S@20 more than anything else, with nominal bug-checking that I suspect is largely done in-house.

I joined up as a PBE tester just this year, and totally agree.

most of my serious bugtesting actually happens in the practice tool on PBE, not in games.

also, there was absolutely no application process. some automated system just checked my honor level and passed me along. I was really disappointed at that.

in my time, I've found a grand total of 2 bugs. one was negated by a tooltip change, the other I have yet to report, because it has next to no impact in actual games.

You mean to say that automating an application process is a bad thing?
You do know that before that, it was the same deal but just with a Rioter doing it by hand?
Now they've added one more requirement and that is to be H3 and higher and not be punished at all.

Bug testing is the major point of PBE though.
If you can't depend on the playerbase to test out the changes for balance purposes, the only thing you can safely take from that is a bit of data to aggregate with your in-house preliminary balance testing and catch any other bugs your in-house team might've missed. The larger the player base, the more variations of gameplay you can get in a day, meaning that bugs (even the most hidden ones) are definitely being discovered faster.

_**Riot has expectations of everyone, even on PBE.**_
Just as your Live account (that i presume you don't want to get banned if you're a total ass), same thing should apply to your PBE account even if you don't spend the same amount of time playing there. It's what a player in good standing would do - a sportsmanlike player. If Riot seriously had to enforce the rules and tie your penalties from PBE on your Live account, how many people do you believe would actually go there and test the content and play on 150 ping, only to risk getting punished?

This is why Riot doesn't enforce those kinds of tied punishments. They do still punish players, just like on Live. Getting your PBE account banned once, Riot won't ever get it back to you again. But, is this actually of consequence to anyone? Not really. People won't intentionally aim to get banned but if they do, they'll just say: "Eh, fuck it".
---

Bottom line is that Riot could probably do something better for PBE but that would require a lot of resources to do and that's not worth it. This is also Blizzard's attitude towards their own PTR for Overwatch. Players asked for incentives for testing the content there and wanted some of those to transfer to their Live accounts and Blizzard said they could do that BUT that it would cut into time and effort from doing stuff for Live and that's not what the majority of players want (as of that time). The player satisfaction and payoff just wasn't there and neither is here in League.

PBE is here and it works. It emulates the same conditions we have on Live.
If the overall gameplay experience is shitty (ignoring the obvious PBE sign of lag spikes, frequent patches, whacky balance changes), it's all on us (the players) that need to improve. And if Riot needs to become a slave driver and get us in line with punishments, that only shows how pathetic of a player base we really are, doesn't it? We're only get in line if there are real consequences to our actions?

How can we then call ourselves sportsmanlike players if this is the reality we live in?
Don't do something you wouldn't do on your Live account, plain and simple.
If you get into a game, respect the players and stay and play to your best ability till the end.
Don't tolerate asses, report them after the game. Do your job to make your stay a bit better.
What do you think would happen if everyone followed these simple steps to the letter?

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=0004000000000001,timestamp=2017-10-26T21:40:19.034+0000)
>
> Bug testing is the major point of PBE though.
> If you can't depend on the playerbase to test out the changes for balance purposes, the only thing you can safely take from that is a bit of data to aggregate with your in-house preliminary balance testing and catch any other bugs your in-house team might've missed. The larger the player base, the more variations of gameplay you can get in a day, meaning that bugs (even the most hidden ones) are definitely being discovered faster.

The same reasoning that can be applied to balance can be applied to bugs here, at least on a broad, qualitative level. The problem isn't that Riot doesn't fine-tune balance around PBE (that I agree is impossible), but that they ignore PBE feedback even when a champion turns out to be grossly out of balance, as is the case for Galio right now. The same goes for clearly abusive interactions, such as Cho'Gath and Gargoyle Stoneplate, to the point where Riot clearly doesn't take _any_ balance feedback, even the bare minimum that doesn't require massive amounts of play to be useful to them.

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=0004000000000001,timestamp=2017-10-26T21:40:19.034+0000)
> 
> If Riot seriously had to enforce the rules and tie your penalties from PBE on your Live account, how many people do you believe would actually go there and test the content and play on 150 ping, only to risk getting punished?

You misunderstand me. The problem is not that Riot doesn't carry punishments over from PBE to Live (that's fine), but that Riot hardly enacts punishments on PBE at all. I'm not talking about players disconnecting or having connection issues, I'm talking about players outright flaming each other and engaging in really toxic behavior in their games. Do you have a PBE account?

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=0004000000000001,timestamp=2017-10-26T21:40:19.034+0000)
> 
> Bottom line is that Riot could probably do something better for PBE but that would require a lot of resources to do and that's not worth it. 

There is a difference between "doing something better" and enacting a minimum set of standards to actually have a testing environment, rather than just a glorified showcase. Purging the PBE of toxic or inactive accounts would be a first step, and enacting a stricter vetting process could have significantly better returns compared to the resources that would be put in. Riot is a major company now, they don't have the excuse of being a small indie company to justify not putting the necessary resources into their own product. If it really isn't worth it, then there is no sense in having a PBE at all; Riot should instead just reveal their content in a few videos ahead of time and push them to Live that way.

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=0004000000000001,timestamp=2017-10-26T21:40:19.034+0000)
> 
> PBE is here and it works.

It really doesn't, as evidenced by the mountains of ignored feedback. Again, do you even have a PBE account? Do you test PBE content with other PBE players? Do you even go on the PBE forums?

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=0004000000000001,timestamp=2017-10-26T21:40:19.034+0000)
> 
> If the overall gameplay experience is shitty (ignoring the obvious PBE sign of lag spikes, frequent patches, whacky balance changes), it's all on us (the players) that need to improve. And if Riot needs to become a slave driver and get us in line with punishments, that only shows how pathetic of a player base we really are, doesn't it? We're only get in line if there are real consequences to our actions?

That's the sad truth to it, but yes, you do need to enact a system of checks and punishments to prevent people from engaging in shitty behavior. The whole of human society does not rely on the mere goodwill of people to not murder each other in order to function; that is why we have legal and judicial systems in place. Again, there is no sense in blaming the players for a system that is poorly structured and managed, particularly since that kind of accusation achieves nothing, even if it makes you feel more righteous than the common rabble you claim to denounce.

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=0004000000000001,timestamp=2017-10-26T21:40:19.034+0000)
> 
> How can we then call ourselves sportsmanlike players if this is the reality we live in?

We don't, the League community is still notoriously toxic. The only reason it has improved is precisely because Riot has finally begun implementing a more robust player behavior system that directs players to be more honorable. Never does any playerbase spontaneously become less toxic on its own, and it's both ridiculous and lazy to expect that to happen with no further effort required.

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=0004000000000001,timestamp=2017-10-26T21:40:19.034+0000)
> 
> Don't do something you wouldn't do on your Live account, plain and simple.

I know that, but what's stopping players from being toxic on the PBE, if there are no consequences to their actions? Do you think the status quo is magically going to change of its own accord?

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=0004000000000001,timestamp=2017-10-26T21:40:19.034+0000)
> 
> If you get into a game, respect the players and stay and play to your best ability till the end.

Again, what's stopping players from just not taking your advice? Why do you think these issues exist now, and what tangible solutions do you propose to resolve them?

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=0004000000000001,timestamp=2017-10-26T21:40:19.034+0000)
> 
> Don't tolerate asses, report them after the game. Do your job to make your stay a bit better.

Except I do report toxic players, yet nothing comes from it. There are players I have reported several times, who other players have reported on many other occasions as well, who continue to play on the PBE and contribute nothing positive, simply because nothing is done to enforce those reports.

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=0004000000000001,timestamp=2017-10-26T21:40:19.034+0000)
> 
> What do you think would happen if everyone followed these simple steps to the letter?

The PBE would become a better place. Again, you're preaching to the choir here, and the issue is that many players don't think in that long-term logical sense. We wouldn't have any toxicity at all otherwise, anywhere or anytime. Going in with this terribly naïve mentality, i.e. that every player is this perfectly logical person, is bound to fail, and if you follow it just a little beyond its premises, it becomes clear that it simply does not apply to the current situation, and is completely useless in trying to resolve the issues underlining negative player behavior.

I do have a PBE account.
I've had one for 2-3 years as a matter of fact.

I know Riot punishes people there because i make it a point to report people on any server i play, because i can't tolerate shit eaters in any shape or form. And i've gotten a few popups that players have been punished on PBE, just like i did on Live. So from my experience, Riot does punish players. The fact of the matter is that even the miniscule number of times people actually report others, they always hold a firm belief that the person they reported has been the absolute scum of the earth and that they deserve to be removed immediately, without any checking.

When this doesn't happen, you'll often see posts like "this player has played one game the next day after feeding his ass off in my previous game so why isn't he dead, Riot?" pop up on occasion.
---
No PBE feedback is ever being ignored, in the same manner you wouldn't see a Rioter answer every question on NA Boards. Rioters are busy people and you can't get a response to every question and piece of feedback you leave. Even if what you say and propose in the said thread, it doesn't have to be fixed in the way (and tomorrow) you want it to be fixed. You give feedback and nothing else. You don't set the priority for Riot nor dictate the balance changes they need to make.

Giving feedback is not a way for us to demand changes to the game.
Giving feedback is yet again, not a replacement for checking the in-game data. How you feel about certain changes doesn't mean the data will ever back up your claims. Riot has to work with tangible evidence. Tangible evidence is their data and your feedback is a complaint about a specific issue they need to check and cross-reference with feedback to see if everything checks out and how can they make it better.

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=000400000000000100000000,timestamp=2017-10-26T22:50:01.640+0000)
> 
> When this doesn't happen, you'll often see posts like "this player has played one game the next day after feeding his ass off in my previous game so why isn't he dead, Riot?" pop up on occasion.

Except Riot has made a point of saying that in the case of truly egregious behavior, players get escalated immediately to a more severe punishment. The fact that this apparently does not seem to happen on PBE which, by all rights, should have even stricter standards of behavior than Live, does show to me that Riot doesn't really put that many resources into moderating PBE players. As much as I'd like to take you up on your word and believe that your reports were effective, the number of feedback threads on the PBE complaining about the toxicity and lack of action taken against it says otherwise. Just the simple fact that there are enough toxic players on the PBE for it to get talked about, when the vetting process should be rigorous enough to only let in dedicated testers and just a few outliers, is already an indicator that there is a problem. 

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=000400000000000100000000,timestamp=2017-10-26T22:50:01.640+0000)
> 
> No PBE feedback is ever being ignored, in the same manner you wouldn't see a Rioter answer every question on NA Boards. Rioters are busy people

So are we, yet we still choose to test in addition to our daily lives and jobs. Taking in feedback, by contrast, _is_ part of Riot's job. PBE is supposed to be an environment for concentrated bug-testing and feedback, so if Riot is too busy to acknowledge even the most basic feedback, then that is entirely on them, and they need to hire more people to work on this.

This also completely fails to acknowledge the many times players have given excellent feedback in large numbers and still gotten ignored. Remember the Mordekaiser update? Literally every single player who tested it gave overwhelmingly negative feedback, yet his kit is the one that changed the least out of the four juggernauts being reworked throughout PBE testing. This wasn't an issue of Riot being "too busy" to do anything, this was Riot deliberately ignoring player feedback and powering through with their own content as if PBE didn't exist. To this day, Mordekaiser has literally dozens of bugs, many of which have been documented since his update released on PBE, yet none of them are being addressed even now.

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=000400000000000100000000,timestamp=2017-10-26T22:50:01.640+0000)
> 
> Giving feedback is not a way for us to demand changes to the game.

Except PBE players tend to do the former, and are treated as if they were doing the latter, as you are trying to do so now. We're not here to wrest control of the game from Riot, but we are here to point out issues we think are important. When a great deal many testers collectively agree that there's a problem, that is not something Riot should ignore.

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=000400000000000100000000,timestamp=2017-10-26T22:50:01.640+0000)
> 
> Giving feedback is yet again, not a replacement for checking the in-game data.

Are you honestly trying to tell me Galio's recent balance changes couldn't have been improved by listening to player feedback? Do you really think we need to wait until a champion or item ends up with a 60+% or 40-% win rate for months on Live before any action gets taken? What's more, Riot has shown on multiple occasions that their own means of interpreting the data is... partial, to say the least, and when they do make the effort of sharing their interpretation with the rest of the playerbase (which only rarely happens), they are very quickly proven wrong and criticized for the flaws in their reasoning.

The problem with both you and, to some degree, Riot, is that you're viewing players as opponents, as people vying for power and control, when the truth is that players are both consumers and a potentially immense asset, in that if you give them the proper tools, they can output tremendously positive contributions, and all for free. As PBE testers, we ask for nothing more than for a serious chance at having our feedback get taken seriously, and even just as players on Live, posting on the Boards, many of us go here because we support Riot, and want to help them. Ignoring and dismissing the playerbase on the grounds that "there aren't enough resources", or that "Riot's just too busy", when Riot Games is literally a billion-dollar company, is complete bullshit, and railing against players giving feedback for supposedly wanting to dictate the course of the entire game is demonstrative of a structural attitude problem, rather than one of resources.

Mordekaiser isn't even an issue anymore.
He's slotted for an eventual VGU because his Juggernaut update didn't pan out right. This was Riot's interlude to more Champion Update/VGU projects which is exactly why they have the teams of people working on both and why the updates are better in quality.

The reason why Morde isn't being touched (or reverted) is simple.
Too much work that's going to get scrapped anyway. Revert was never going to happen because his old version wasn't better. Fixing his bugs is a fool's errand because none of them are gamebreaking or impossible to deal with. If there's indeed over 100 Morde bugs, that would require his entire code to be combed through - not just fixing a few values here and there.

Riven's Edge mechanic didn't make it to Live.
Neither did Lee's changes. That's the result of feedback and Riot's whacky testing that perhaps were never meant to go live in any way. In any case, Riot isn't required to take action based on your feedback. It's always taken into account if you leave it but it doesn't mean Riot will act on it immediately.

>the number of feedback threads on the PBE complaining about the toxicity and lack of action taken against it says otherwise. Just the simple fact that there are enough toxic players on the PBE for it to get talked about,

Boards are like an echo chamber. Any kind of a sound will propagate throughout the room. You just need to strategically stand in the spot that carries it the most.

_**People who never have an issue with anything won't even come to participate in any discussions.**_ So all you see here is mostly complaints from people and if you take Boards as the actual of the state of the game, you'd get the impression as if the game is never properly balanced, despite being active for 8 years and still going strong.

>The problem with both you and, to some degree, Riot, is that you're viewing players as opponents,

The way people talk with Riot on Boards is the reason why i think of players as opponents. This ties very nicely in my previous point about how people choose to word their complaints when leaving "feedback" to Riot. Being an ass, insulting people and demanding attention is the reason why i refuse to even comment on some of those threads because it's pointless to enter a discussion when the entire thread isn't even interested in one. As if the OP (and others supporting him) just came there to vent off some steam and fellate themselves about who's better at insulting.

>"Riot's just too busy", when Riot Games is literally a billion-dollar company

I find this argument worn out already.
What if Riot's a billion dollar company? Does that somehow magically exempt them from still working as a regular company or do you believe that throwing enough money at a specific problem will magically make it disappear?

Riot can be too busy.
Right now, the majority of their resources are tied to the pre-season and balance changes to the new runes + masteries. This is their top priority project. I'm sorry that they can't take your own priority list a look but the reality of the situation is that Riot is a big company and their own picture of our entire playerbase and balance changes is the big picture. Not something you look at from your own perspective. Since pre-season runes aren't on Live, this is the PBE feedback they're now taking into consideration when balancing them.

When you look at Censer problem, you think that only nerfing it would fix the problem and that might be the case. But Riot's job is to take a look at Censer and every other champion that buys it/uses it and seeing if perhaps they aren't the problem or identifying something about their kits that was overtuned. Perhaps the item works as intended but the champions using it push it the the limits.

You (we as individual players) look at balance of League through a narrow lense while Riot looks at it through a wide lense. And this is always somehow ignored when we're talking about Riot "taking their sweet ass time at nerfing shit and sitting on their hands counting money". It's always Riot that's apparently lazy, too slow to react and not interested in actual fair balance while we are the exemplar members of our pristine community that can only be described as good players for bringing these problems to their attention...

If Riot needs to punish players in order to get us in line (as we've discussed earlier), we're definitely not the exemplar members of our community. I'm becoming increasingly more apathetic towards the Boards because all i see here is the absolute worst of the worst. Let's find some balance between leaving neutral feedback and opening ourselves for discussions instead of having the first thing leaving our mouths beeing insults.

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=00040000000000010000000000000000,timestamp=2017-10-27T10:26:14.521+0000)
>
> Mordekaiser isn't even an issue anymore.

Except he is. He got a lot of balance work over the years, and so is better than on his update's release, but he still has an insane amount of bugs, along with quite a few mechanics that are universally loathed (his W passive, for example). Just take a look at MM's threads, including the ones where he exhaustively lists all of the champion's bugs.

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=00040000000000010000000000000000,timestamp=2017-10-27T10:26:14.521+0000)
> 
> Too much work that's going to get scrapped anyway. Revert was never going to happen because his old version wasn't better. Fixing his bugs is a fool's errand because none of them are gamebreaking or impossible to deal with. If there's indeed over 100 Morde bugs, that would require his entire code to be combed through - not just fixing a few values here and there.

But several of his bugs _are_ game-breaking, and his previous self _was_ better, even if it wasn't great. Again, you should take a look at MM's bug documentation for him.

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=00040000000000010000000000000000,timestamp=2017-10-27T10:26:14.521+0000)
> 
> Riven's Edge mechanic didn't make it to Live.

A handful of changes didn't make it to Live, not because of feedback, but because the features themselves are beyond experimental and the tester was simply using the PBE to see how it'd turn out. The same happened with some changes to Muramana a while back. To be honest, I'd like to see this more often, though it doesn't feel like we as testers have real agency over how these tests pan out.

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=00040000000000010000000000000000,timestamp=2017-10-27T10:26:14.521+0000)
> 
> Boards are like an echo chamber.

What, so we should just pretend Boards doesn't exist? I agree that there is an echo chamber effect, but the Boards tend to be pretty accurate when it comes to hot-button issues, so if a large number of posts complain about a specific problem, chances are there's a problem.

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=00040000000000010000000000000000,timestamp=2017-10-27T10:26:14.521+0000)
> 
> _**People who never have an issue with anything won't even come to participate in any discussions.**_ 

I am well aware of that, but while League is a game that has been going strong for 8 years, it is also a game that has been in constant ongoing development for that same amount of time. I do wish Gameplay could take a step back and realize that the game isn't on this constant downhill slope, as so many regulars have fallen into believing, but in the end much of their criticism is still useful, as League has never been perfect in its lifetime, and could stand to improve significantly more.

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=00040000000000010000000000000000,timestamp=2017-10-27T10:26:14.521+0000)
> 
> The way people talk with Riot on Boards is the reason why i think of players as opponents. 

To some extent, I agree that the the attitude of many players here is toxic, and shouldn't be happening. Part of the problem I think comes from the Reddit-style structure of the Boards, which encourages some posters to write empty, low-effort threads just for the sake of getting upvotes. I also think part of the problem comes from any video game feedback forum, in that some players go beyond giving feedback and instead vent their frustrations at their in-game losses. These, however, are structural problems, problems that Riot has made no effort to address, and should not discredit the players actually making an effort to try to help. Moreover, Riot's infrequent and unreliable communication schedule adds fuel to the fire, as it does add to the impression that the devs ignore players and only answer the easy questions, yet still want to call themselves good player communicators. Again, venting on game forums is pretty much the standard, as unfortunate as that is, so it really is up to Riot to improve on their communication, which they haven't really done in the past few years.

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=00040000000000010000000000000000,timestamp=2017-10-27T10:26:14.521+0000)
> 
> I find this argument worn out already.
> What if Riot's a billion dollar company? Does that somehow magically exempt them from still working as a regular company or do you believe that throwing enough money at a specific problem will magically make it disappear?

That's the thing, though: in many ways, Riot isn't working as a regular company, they're working as if they were still a startup. This is why their communications strategy has aged so badly, because their developers simply do not have the time to also take on the full-time job of communicating with the playerbase. This is a situation where hiring more people with the specific goal of communicating with players, something that Riot can clearly afford to do, would greatly benefit them. It is ridiculous to call a company's vast success and wealth "a worn out argument".

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=00040000000000010000000000000000,timestamp=2017-10-27T10:26:14.521+0000)
> 
> Right now, the majority of their resources are tied to the pre-season and balance changes to the new runes + masteries.

And this costs a billion dollars? Do you have any understanding of how a company works? Riot is a company with only one game still, and while much of their income undoubtedly goes towards servers, engineering, ongoing art and stuff, the company is sure as hell not putting all of their massive income directly into design, nor are they strapped for cash, so they can absolutely afford to hire an actual player relations team.

> [{quoted}](name=Elikain,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EooAQumE,comment-id=00040000000000010000000000000000,timestamp=2017-10-27T10:26:14.521+0000)
> 
> When you look at Censer problem, you think that only nerfing it would fix the problem and that might be the case. But Riot's job is to take a look at Censer and every other champion that buys it/uses it and seeing if perhaps they aren't the problem or identifying something about their kits that was overtuned. Perhaps the item works as intended but the champions using it push it the the limits.
